input_args.examples: {'document_id': ['0000803', '0000803', '0000803', '0000803'], 'document_source': ['GHR', 'GHR', 'GHR', 'GHR'], 'document_url': ['https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/poland-syndrome', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/poland-syndrome', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/poland-syndrome', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/poland-syndrome'], 'category': [None, None, None, None], 'umls_cui': ['C0032357', 'C0032357', 'C0032357', 'C0032357'], 'umls_semantic_types': ['T019|T047', 'T019|T047', 'T019|T047', 'T019|T047'], 'umls_semantic_group': ['Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders'], 'synonyms': ["Poland anomaly|Poland sequence|Poland syndactyly|Poland's anomaly|Poland's syndrome|unilateral defect of pectoralis major and syndactyly of the hand", "Poland anomaly|Poland sequence|Poland syndactyly|Poland's anomaly|Poland's syndrome|unilateral defect of pectoralis major and syndactyly of the hand", "Poland anomaly|Poland sequence|Poland syndactyly|Poland's anomaly|Poland's syndrome|unilateral defect of pectoralis major and syndactyly of the hand", "Poland anomaly|Poland sequence|Poland syndactyly|Poland's anomaly|Poland's syndrome|unilateral defect of pectoralis major and syndactyly of the hand"], 'question_id': ['0000803-2', '0000803-3', '0000803-4', '0000803-5'], 'question_focus': ['Poland syndrome', 'Poland syndrome', 'Poland syndrome', 'Poland syndrome'], 'question_type': ['frequency', 'genetic changes', 'inheritance', 'treatment'], 'question': ['How many people are affected by Poland syndrome ?', 'What are the genetic changes related to Poland syndrome ?', 'Is Poland syndrome inherited ?', 'What are the treatments for Poland syndrome ?'], 'answer': ['Poland syndrome has been estimated to occur in 1 in 20,000 newborns. For unknown reasons, this disorder occurs more than twice as often in males than in females. Poland syndrome may be underdiagnosed because mild cases without hand involvement may never come to medical attention.', 'The cause of Poland syndrome is unknown. Researchers have suggested that it may result from a disruption of blood flow during development before birth. This disruption is thought to occur at about the sixth week of embryonic development and affect blood vessels that will become the subclavian and vertebral arteries on each side of the body. The arteries normally supply blood to embryonic tissues that give rise to the chest wall and hand on their respective sides. Variations in the site and extent of the disruption may explain the range of signs and symptoms that occur in Poland syndrome. Abnormality of an embryonic structure called the apical ectodermal ridge, which helps direct early limb development, may also be involved in this disorder.  Rare cases of Poland syndrome are thought to be caused by a genetic change that can be passed down in families, but no related genes have been identified.', 'Most cases of Poland syndrome are sporadic, which means they are not inherited and occur in people with no history of the disorder in their families. Rarely, this condition is passed through generations in families. In these families the condition appears to be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of an altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder, although no associated genes have been found.', "These resources address the diagnosis or management of Poland syndrome:  - Children's Medical Center of Dallas  - Great Ormond Street Hospital (UK): Treatment Options for Symbrachydactyly  - St. Louis Children's Hospital: Chest Wall Deformities   These resources from MedlinePlus offer information about the diagnosis and management of various health conditions:  - Diagnostic Tests  - Drug Therapy  - Surgery and Rehabilitation  - Genetic Counseling   - Palliative Care"]}
